[H1] BASIC PROCESSES OF THE GI TRACT.
[H1] BASIC PROCESSES OF THE GI TRACT.
The chemical breakdown of food into molecules able to be absorbed
[H1] Overall Fluid Balance of the GI Tract.
Saliva Gastric Juice Bile Pancreatic Juice Intestinal
Cephalic Stimuli taste, smell, sight, emotions
Gastric and Intestinal Luminal Stimuli mechanoreceptors - volume, pressure chemoreceptors - amino acids, fatty acids, pH osmoreceptors - osmolarity

Solid lines represent preganglionic and broken lines represent postganglionic fibers.

[H1] BLOCK DIAGRAM FOR NEURAL CONTROL OF THE GI TRACT.
GENERAL PROCESSES AFFECTED BY GI REGULATORY MOLECULES
[H1] MORPHOLOGY AND SECRETION BY GI ENDOCRINE CELLS.
[H1] MORPHOLOGY AND SECRETION BY GI ENDOCRINE CELLS.
G-4 minimal active fragment shared with CCK G-5 Pentagastrin (synthetic) G-17 "little" gastrin → Exist as both non-sulfated G-34 "big" gastrin → and sulfated forms
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Synthesized by G cells in gastric antrum
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Released in response to food in stomach
CCK-8 CCK-33 CCK-58 > All contain sulfated tyrosine
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Synthesized by I cells in duodenal and upper jejunal mucosa
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Released in response to peptides and fatty acids in lumen of small intestine
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Stimulation of Bile and Pancreatic $\mathrm{HCO}_3$ Secretion
Secretin is synthesized by S cells in the duodenal mucosa and released in response to acid (pH < 4.5) in the duodenal lumen
Synthesized and released from a distinct type of duodenal endocrine cell in response to luminal nutrients
Found in both pancreas and gut but processed in islets to glucagon and in gut to GLP-1 and GLP-2
Widely distributed neuropeptide most often inhibitory to muscle but stimulates glandular secretion. Tumors (VIPomas) result in secretory diarrhea
Histamine – paracrine regulator; major stimulant of gastric acid secretion
Bombesin or GRP (Gastrin Releasing Peptide) – neuropeptide; stimulates gastrin release
Motilin – intestinal GI hormone; regulates intestinal motility (MMC)
Enkephalins – neurocrine regulators of motility and secretion
Somatostatin – universal inhibitory paracrine or endocrine regulatory peptide
GLP-1 (glucagon-like peptide 1) – formed by postranslational processing of proglucagon in intestine.
An important regulator of insulin secretion and appetite
GLP-2 (glucagon-like peptide 2) – stimulates growth of intestinal mucosa
Growth and Trophic Factors – Insulin, TGF $\alpha$, IGF
Ghrelin – oriexigenic peptide present in the gastric mucosa
Fig. 1-2 Granger, D, et al. Clinical Gastrointestinal Physiology. W.B. Saunders, Philadelphia, PA; 1985: 7.
